image-wrap.caption: Schematic of the Knarr field subsea infrastructure

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of the Knarr field subsea infrastructure

linkTarget.anchoringText: The bean-up guide provided was adhered to as much as operations allowed. During the flowback of the completion fluids, topside valves upstream of the test separator were continuously blocked by completion fluid and resolving this issue slowed the bean-up rate during the clean-up period. Also, the drawdowns experienced during the clean-up periods were not in line with expectations based on mobility data acquired while drilling the reservoir section of the well. Figure 3 shows data acquired during the A-1H clean-up period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: A-1H Well test – Clean-up flow period

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-1H Well test – Clean-up flow period

linkTarget.anchoringText: The decision was taken to proceed with the first main flow period. During the main flow period, the drawdowns were monitored throughout the bean-up to maximum well rates. Screen plugging was ruled out as reason for the excessive drawdowns observed (up to 50 bar drawdown) as there was no corresponding decrease in production rates at constant choke opening. It was suspected that there was a restriction in the well somewhere upstream of the PDHG. Figure 4 and Figure 5 show the well test results from the first main flow period.

caption.i: A-1H Well test – 1st Main flow period

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-1H Well test – 1st Main flow period

linkTarget.anchoringText: The decision was taken to proceed with the first main flow period. During the main flow period, the drawdowns were monitored throughout the bean-up to maximum well rates. Screen plugging was ruled out as reason for the excessive drawdowns observed (up to 50 bar drawdown) as there was no corresponding decrease in production rates at constant choke opening. It was suspected that there was a restriction in the well somewhere upstream of the PDHG. Figure 4 and Figure 5 show the well test results from the first main flow period.

caption.i: A-1H Well test - 1st Main flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-1H Well test - 1st Main flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The decision was taken to have an additional flow period as the true well productivity had not yet been confirmed. Figure 6 and Figure 7 show the results from the additional flow period (second main flow) undertaken. From Figure 7 it can be observed that whereas up to 50 bar drawdown was required to flow at a maximum rate of 1,420 Sm3/day during the first main flow period, the drawdown required to achieve a maximum rate of 1,350 Sm3/day in the additional flow period was only 6.5 bar.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: A-1H Well test – 2nd Main flow period

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-1H Well test – 2nd Main flow period

linkTarget.anchoringText: The decision was taken to have an additional flow period as the true well productivity had not yet been confirmed. Figure 6 and Figure 7 show the results from the additional flow period (second main flow) undertaken. From Figure 7 it can be observed that whereas up to 50 bar drawdown was required to flow at a maximum rate of 1,420 Sm3/day during the first main flow period, the drawdown required to achieve a maximum rate of 1,350 Sm3/day in the additional flow period was only 6.5 bar.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: A-1H Well test – 2nd Main flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-1H Well test – 2nd Main flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: With a ‘live well’ confirmed and the TDP confirmed to be shattered, the well was opened on 8/64th inch (see Figure 8 and Figure 9 for clean-up results). A gas alarm in the lab cabin during the clean-up flow period meant that the well was shut-in at surface. Although most of the completion fluid had already been flowed back to surface, the decision was taken to continue the clean-up flow period for the allotted total duration of 6 hours as per the well test plan (see appendix for well test plan and clean-up procedure document).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: A-2H Well test - Clean-up flow period

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-2H Well test - Clean-up flow period

linkTarget.anchoringText: With a ‘live well’ confirmed and the TDP confirmed to be shattered, the well was opened on 8/64th inch (see Figure 8 and Figure 9 for clean-up results). A gas alarm in the lab cabin during the clean-up flow period meant that the well was shut-in at surface. Although most of the completion fluid had already been flowed back to surface, the decision was taken to continue the clean-up flow period for the allotted total duration of 6 hours as per the well test plan (see appendix for well test plan and clean-up procedure document).

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: A-2H Well test - Clean-up flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-2H Well test - Clean-up flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: After the initial PBU period, the well was opened for the main flow. The well bean-up guide was adhered to during the well bean-up to maximum rates. The results from the main flow period can be seen in Figure 10 and Figure 11. It can be observed that at every choke opening the FBHP appears to be decreasing continuously. This is explained by the presence of faults (boundaries) close to the well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: A-2H Well test – Main flow period

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-2H Well test – Main flow period

linkTarget.anchoringText: After the initial PBU period, the well was opened for the main flow. The well bean-up guide was adhered to during the well bean-up to maximum rates. The results from the main flow period can be seen in Figure 10 and Figure 11. It can be observed that at every choke opening the FBHP appears to be decreasing continuously. This is explained by the presence of faults (boundaries) close to the well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: A-2H Well test – Main flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-2H Well test – Main flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Shortly after gas flaring commenced, a leak was observed on a flange on the vent line of the flare boom which meant that the well had to be shut-in until the leak was repaired. The well was started up shortly afterwards and the clean-up continued. The oil flowrate was ramped up to a maximum of circa 1,400 Sm3/day and a tubing volume was produced at this rate before the well was shut-in for the planned initial PBU. The clean-up results are as shown in Figure 12 and Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: A-4H Well test - Clean-up flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-4H Well test - Clean-up flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Shortly after gas flaring commenced, a leak was observed on a flange on the vent line of the flare boom which meant that the well had to be shut-in until the leak was repaired. The well was started up shortly afterwards and the clean-up continued. The oil flowrate was ramped up to a maximum of circa 1,400 Sm3/day and a tubing volume was produced at this rate before the well was shut-in for the planned initial PBU. The clean-up results are as shown in Figure 12 and Figure 13.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: A-4H Well test - Clean-up flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-4H Well test - Clean-up flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results were more pessimistic than the post drill expectations with the drawdown required to produce at the maximum rate achieved circa 6 bar more than expected. The drawdown rate during the main flow period is estimated at circa 2.3 bar/hr. Unlike A-2H, although the required drawdown to produce at maximum rate is higher (27 bar for A-4H versus 17 bar for A-2H), the rate of decline in FBHP is negligible which could indicate that A-4H is connected to more reservoir volumes. The results from the main flow period are presented in Figure 14 and Figure 15 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: A-4H Well test – Main flow flow period

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-4H Well test – Main flow flow period

linkTarget.anchoringText: The results were more pessimistic than the post drill expectations with the drawdown required to produce at the maximum rate achieved circa 6 bar more than expected. The drawdown rate during the main flow period is estimated at circa 2.3 bar/hr. Unlike A-2H, although the required drawdown to produce at maximum rate is higher (27 bar for A-4H versus 17 bar for A-2H), the rate of decline in FBHP is negligible which could indicate that A-4H is connected to more reservoir volumes. The results from the main flow period are presented in Figure 14 and Figure 15 below.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: A-4H Well test – Main flow flow period (2)

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-4H Well test – Main flow flow period (2)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Where appropriate, a lumped productivity index with a single zone representing all reservoir units is used as in the case of A-1H. If deemed necessary and when a substantial productivity index difference is expected, the reservoir is further partitioned with each zone defined as per its expected productivity. In the A-4H case illustrated in Figure 16, the wellbore is setup using 2 well inflow zones with a performance inflow corresponding to the productivity index based on the in-situ reservoir properties of the Upper and Lower Cook sand respectively.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Knarr Well Schematic and Wellbore Fluid Initialization prior to the cleanup

formatted-caption.caption-text: Knarr Well Schematic and Wellbore Fluid Initialization prior to the cleanup

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Well trajectories for Knarr West and Central Oil Producers

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well trajectories for Knarr West and Central Oil Producers

linkTarget.anchoringText: The following Casing Scheme (Figure 18) was used in the modeling of the A-4H Oil Producer. The model was constructed with the appropriate physical (ID, Wall thickness, roughness, length, top of cement, annular fluid, etc.…) and thermal properties (density, heat capacity, conductivity, etc.…) as provided in the basis for design and.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Casing Schematic with Riser for well unload

formatted-caption.caption-text: Casing Schematic with Riser for well unload

image-wrap.caption: Fluid phase envelop

linkTarget.anchoringText: The well shut-in event (due to the vent line leak) was included in the simulation as shown in Figure 21 by reducing choke opening to zero for 31.8 minutes followed by choke ramp-up to 20/64th inch. Figure 21 shows predicted completion fluid and oil flowrates at the rig during the 9-hour well clean-up agree with measurement data quite well; albeit calculated oil flowrate between 7.23 and 7.67 hours shows a response based on a choke opening increase to 26/64th inch, whereas measured oil rate shows a constant level without any obvious increase.

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: A-4H well water flowrates and oil flowrates at rig during well cleanup

formatted-caption.caption-text: A-4H well water flowrates and oil flowrates at rig during well cleanup

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 21 shows predicted completion fluid and oil flowrates at the rig during the 9-hour well clean-up agree with measurement data quite well; albeit calculated oil flowrate between 7.23 and 7.67 hours shows a response based on a choke opening increase to 26/64th inch, whereas measured oil rate shows a constant level without any obvious increase. The simulation also revealed the reservoir inflow contributions from each reservoir unit with respect to choke schedule, as shown in Figure 22.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Simulated mass flowrates from Upper Cook and Lower Cook

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated mass flowrates from Upper Cook and Lower Cook

linkTarget.anchoringText: The LSOBM rig arrival time was predicted to be 3.51 hours, and entire unloading period was 6.7 hours, shown in Figure 23. Field records indicate it took 3.5 hours for the first traces of oil based mud to arrive at surface and a total of 6.5 hours to achieve the clean-up criteria of <1% BS&W. A total of 62 m3 of completion fluid was displaced from the well to slop tanks during the clean-up before any hydrocarbons were observed at surface which matches wells with the simulation prediction of 64 m3 (see Figure 23). The results also show it takes approximately 4.2 hours to unload NaBr.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Simulated mass flowrates at rig for NaBr and LSOBM along with accumulated volume flows for water and oil phases at rig

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated mass flowrates at rig for NaBr and LSOBM along with accumulated volume flows for water and oil phases at rig

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 24 illustrates the mass fraction profiles of NaBr (a) and LSOBM (b) at various time stamps to demonstrate the displacement of the different fluid phases as they move along the production tubing from the bottom of the well to the rig. The simulation captured the drilling mud arrival time at rig accurately and it verifies the BS&W measurement to be <1% which agrees with the tracer sampling results at the end of clean-up operation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Displacement profile of NaBr mud along the production tubing and riser; (b) Displacement profile of LSOBM along the production tubing and riser

formatted-caption.caption-text: Displacement profile of NaBr mud along the production tubing and riser; (b) Displacement profile of LSOBM along the production tubing and riser

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Displacement profile of NaBr mud along the production tubing and riser
Displacement profile of LSOBM along the production tubing and riser

linkTarget.anchoringText: Calculated pressure and temperature at DHPT gauge depth (3,866 m MD) are plotted in Figure 25 to compare against measured data points. It shows simulation results capture the trends of downhole pressure and temperature changes. Discrepancy in pressure is observed from 0 to 0.8 hours and is explained due to the ‘stiff’ full liquid system at initial conditions. A better match was achieved once formation fluid begins flowing into wellbore, thus small simulation time steps are crucial to improve the model accuracy.

image-wrap.label: Figure 25
image-wrap.caption: Simulated pressure and temperature values comparing with DHPT gauge measured pressure and temperature during clean-up period

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated pressure and temperature values comparing with DHPT gauge measured pressure and temperature during clean-up period

linkTarget.anchoringText: A sensitivity study was performed to acquire the representative choke diameter to better capture the pressure loss due to the flow restriction. As shown in Figure 26, calculated BHP matches the measured BHP quite well for most of the clean-up, except for the discrepancy observed between 4 to 5 hours. The noticeable increased downhole pressure measurements were due to plugging of the choke. During this period, calculated BHP is lower than measured data as the choke size in the model doesn’t reflect this plugging incident.

image-wrap.label: Figure 26
image-wrap.caption: Calculated liquid flowrates and BHP comparing with field measurements from A-1H

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calculated liquid flowrates and BHP comparing with field measurements from A-1H

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the field reports, during the subsequent main flow period, traces of LSOBM was still being flowed back despite the initial clean-up suggesting the well had cleaned up to BS&W <1%. This field observation was supported by simulation results as shown in Figure 27. The movements of both NaBr and LOSBM at various time stamps during the clean-up are presented through 3D animation in Figure 28. It depicts LSOBM arrival on the rig at 3.35 hour.

image-wrap.label: Figure 27
image-wrap.caption: Simulated A-1H mass flowrates and total mass amounts in wellbore for NaBr and LSOBM

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated A-1H mass flowrates and total mass amounts in wellbore for NaBr and LSOBM

linkTarget.anchoringText: According to the field reports, during the subsequent main flow period, traces of LSOBM was still being flowed back despite the initial clean-up suggesting the well had cleaned up to BS&W <1%. This field observation was supported by simulation results as shown in Figure 27. The movements of both NaBr and LOSBM at various time stamps during the clean-up are presented through 3D animation in Figure 28. It depicts LSOBM arrival on the rig at 3.35 hour.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 29 shows history matching results for BHP and liquid flowrates of A-2H. The flowrate calculation prior to the emergency shut-in matches with measured data reasonably well, except there is a gap between 3.2 and 4.25 hours where no flowrate records are available, thus no comparison was made. However, simulation results show the expected response with respect to the rig valve ramp up from 20/64th inch to 32/64th inch and subsequent choke-back to 24/64th inch during this period.

image-wrap.label: Figure 29
image-wrap.caption: Calculated liquid flowrates and BHP comparing with field measurements from A-2H

formatted-caption.caption-text: Calculated liquid flowrates and BHP comparing with field measurements from A-2H

linkTarget.anchoringText: During the shut-in, calculated BHP agrees with gauge measurement in general, although discrepancies exist at the beginning of the shut-in; measured BHP shows a gradual increase before reaching equilibrium whereas simulation established the static BHP much faster. Again, this can be explained by the lack of a near wellbore model coupled to the simulator. Additionally, Figure 30 shows that most of the NaBr and LSOBM were cleaned up before the shut-in, which verifies the field records.

image-wrap.label: Figure 30
image-wrap.caption: Simulated A-2H mass flowrates and total mass amounts in wellbore for NaBr and LSOBM

formatted-caption.caption-text: Simulated A-2H mass flowrates and total mass amounts in wellbore for NaBr and LSOBM

image-wrap.caption: Dynamic model clean-up time sensitivity results

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dynamic model clean-up time sensitivity results
